column1: The subjunctive in the {{c1::present::tense(s)}} has rules for formation that vary slightly among the four conjugations; rules for forming the subjunctive in the {{c1::imperfect, perfect, and pluperfect::tense(s)}} are the same for all conjugations, even for {{c1::irregular verbs}}.

What is the mnemonic "we fear a liar" for, and where should macrons fall within it? {{c1::To remember what vowel(s) precede the personal endings for the 1/2/3/4,3io conjugations' present subjunctive forms respectively, for both active and passive voices, and: wē, feār, ā, liār.}}

subjunctive case use: Jussive . {{c1::The sentence's main (and perhaps only) verb is in the subjunctive, possibly introduced by nē for negative commands, esp. for 1st and 3rd person. (2nd generally uses imperative mood). . 2nd person (rare), and rarely with 1st and 3rd: "may"/"should"; commonly with 1st and 3rd: "let" followed by the subject noun or pronoun in objective case.::how to recognize . translation}} .

subjunctive case use: {{c1::Jussive::subjunctive of ___}} . The sentence's main (and perhaps only) verb is in the subjunctive, possibly introduced by nē for negative commands, esp. for 1st and 3rd person. (2nd generally uses imperative mood). . {{c1::2nd person (rare), and rarely with 1st and 3rd: "may"/"should"; commonly with 1st and 3rd: "let" followed by the subject noun or pronoun in objective case.::translation}} .

subjunctive case use: {{c1::Jussive . The sentence's main (and perhaps only) verb is in the subjunctive, possibly introduced by nē for negative commands, esp. for 1st and 3rd person. (2nd generally uses imperative mood).::subjunctive of ___ . how to recognize}} . 2nd person (rare), and rarely with 1st and 3rd: "may"/"should"; commonly with 1st and 3rd: "let" followed by the subject noun or pronoun in objective case. .

subjunctive case use: Purpose . {{c1::"Ut" or "nē" introducing a subordinate clause in the subjunctive stating the purpose of the action in the main clause . "May" often in the present tense, esp. when subordinate and main clauses have different subjects; an infinitive ("to") or "in order to" when subordinate and main clauses have the same subject.::how to recognize . translation}} .

subjunctive case use: {{c1::Purpose::subjunctive of ___}} . "Ut" or "nē" introducing a subordinate clause in the subjunctive stating the purpose of the action in the main clause . {{c1::"May" often in the present tense, esp. when subordinate and main clauses have different subjects; an infinitive ("to") or "in order to" when subordinate and main clauses have the same subject.::translation}} .

subjunctive case use: {{c1::Purpose . "Ut" or "nē" introducing a subordinate clause in the subjunctive stating the purpose of the action in the main clause::subjunctive of ___ . how to recognize}} . "May" often in the present tense, esp. when subordinate and main clauses have different subjects; an infinitive ("to") or "in order to" when subordinate and main clauses have the same subject. .
{{c1::árma, armṓrum}} has gender {{c2::n. pl.}} and means {{c3::arms, weapons}} with English derivatives {{c1::army armament, armada, amistice, armadillo, gendarme, alarm}}

{{c1::cúrsus, cúrsūs}} has gender {{c2::m}} and means {{c3::running, race; course}} with English derivatives {{c1::courser, cursor, cursory, cursive, concourse, discourse, recourse, precursor, excursion; cf. currō}}
{{c1::lū́na, lū́nae}} has gender {{c2::f}} and means {{c3::moon}} with English derivatives {{c1::lunar, lunacy, lunate, lunatic, interlunar}}
{{c1::occā́siō, occāsiṓnis}} has gender {{c2::f}} and means {{c3::occasion, opportunity}} with English derivatives {{c1::occasional}}
{{c1::párēns, paréntis}} has gender {{c2::m or f}} and means {{c3::parent}} with English derivatives {{c1::parental, parenting; cf. pariō, parere}}
{{c1::páriō, párere, péperī, pártum}} means {{c3::beget, produce; give birth to}} with English derivatives {{c1::parental, parenting}}
{{c1::stḗlla, stḗllae}} has gender {{c2::f}} and means {{c3::star, planet}} with English derivatives {{c1::stellar, constellation, interstellar}}
{{c1::vésper, vésperis OR vésper, vésperī (OR perhaps even véspera, vésperae)}} has gender {{c2::m}} and means {{c3::evening; evening star}} with English derivatives {{c1::vesper, vesperal}}
{{c1::mórtuus, mórtua, mórtuum}} means {{c3::dead}} with English derivatives {{c1::mortuary}}
{{c1::prī́nceps, gen. prī́ncipis}} means {{c3::chief, foremost}} with English derivatives {{c1::prince, principal, principality; cf. prīmus, prīncipium}}
{{c1::prī́nceps, prī́ncipis (substantively)}} has gender {{c2::m or f}} and means {{c3::leader, emperor}} with English derivatives {{c1::prince, principal, principality; cf. prīmus, prīncipium}}
{{c1::nē}} is a/an {{c4::adv. and conj. with subjunct. of command and purpose}} and means {{c3::not; in order that ... not, that ... not, in order not to}}

{{c1::cḗdō, cḗdere, céssī, céssum}} means {{c3::to go, withdraw; yield to, grant, submit}} with English derivatives {{c1::accede, access, antecedent, ancestor, cede, concede, deceased, exceed, intercede, precede, proceed, recede, secede; cf. discēdō}}
{{c1::dḗdicō, dēdicā́re, dēdicā́vī, dēdicā́tum}} means {{c3::to dedicate}} with English derivatives {{c1::dedication, dedicatory}}
{{c1::égeō, egḗre, éguī + abl. or gen.}} means {{c3::to need, to lack, to want}} with English derivatives {{c1::indigence, indigent; do not confuse with ēgī from agō}}
{{c1::éxpleō, explḗre, explḗvī, explḗtum}} means {{c3::to fill, fill up, complete}} with English derivatives {{c1::expletive, deplete, replete; cf. plēnus, pleō}}
{{c1::pléō, plḗre, plḗvī, plḗtum}} means {{c3::to fill}} with English derivatives {{c1::deplete, replete; cf. expleō}}
{{c1::praéstō, praestā́re, praéstitī, praēstitum}} means {{c3::to excel; exhibit, show, offer, supply, furnish}} with English derivatives {{c1::presto}}
{{c1::táceō, tacḗre, tácuī, tácitum}} means {{c3::to be silent, leave unmentioned}} with English derivatives {{c1::tacit, taciturn, taciturnity, reticence, reticent}}
